unnormalised: Okay, folks, buckle up! Today, we're diving into the somewhat chaotic, yet absolutely vital, world of traffic regulations in India. Let's face it, navigating the roads from Delhi to Dindigul can feel like an extreme sport.
normalised: Okay, folks, buckle up! Today, we're diving into the somewhat chaotic, yet absolutely vital, world of traffic regulations in India. Let's face it, navigating the roads from Delhi to Dindigul can feel like an extreme sport.

unnormalised: First off, remember the basics: always wear your helmet (especially two-wheeler riders!). Dr. Sharma at AIIMS says head injuries are a major concern. And seatbelts aren't just for show, people! They're there to save your life.
normalised: First off, remember the basics: always wear your helmet (especially two-wheeler riders!). Doctor Sharma at A I I M S says head injuries are a major concern. And seatbelts aren't just for show, people! They're there to save your life.

unnormalised: Speed limits, ah yes. In cities like Mumbai, you're generally looking at around 40-50 kmph, but on highways, it can go up to 80-100 kmph. Keep an eye out for those signboards, even if you think you know the road like the back of your hand. They change faster than the price of petrol!
normalised: Speed limits, ah yes. In cities like Mumbai, you're generally looking at around forty to fifty kilometer per hour, but on highways, it can go up to eighty to one hundred kilometer per hour. Keep an eye out for those signboards, even if you think you know the road like the back of your hand. They change faster than the price of petrol!

unnormalised: Then there's the whole lane discipline thing. While theoretically, we're supposed to stay in our lane, reality is often…different. Let's just say defensive driving is key. Think like a chess grandmaster anticipating your opponent's next (often unpredictable) move. And honking doesn't magically make traffic disappear. It just adds to the already impressive noise pollution.
normalised: Then there's the whole lane discipline thing. While theoretically, we're supposed to stay in our lane, reality is often…different. Let's just say defensive driving is key. Think like a chess grandmaster anticipating your opponent's next (often unpredictable) move. And honking doesn't magically make traffic disappear. It just adds to the already impressive noise pollution.

unnormalised: Parking is another battlefield. Finding a legal parking spot in Connaught Place is rarer than spotting a unicorn. And be warned, illegal parking can lead to hefty fines, sometimes upwards of Rs. 500-Rs. 2000. Not worth it! Plus, your car could get towed.
normalised: Parking is another battlefield. Finding a legal parking spot in Connaught Place is rarer than spotting a unicorn. And be warned, illegal parking can lead to hefty fines, sometimes upwards of rupee five hundred to rupee two thousand. Not worth it! Plus, your car could get towed.

unnormalised: Remember that RTO rules also apply to the size of your banner or sticker on your vehicle. No advertising billboards on your Nano! Ensure enough visibility as a car showroom with massive glass frontage (at least 1500 sq ft!).
normalised: Remember that R T O rules also apply to the size of your banner or sticker on your vehicle. No advertising billboards on your Nano! Ensure enough visibility as a car showroom with massive glass frontage (at least one thousand five hundred square feet!).

unnormalised: Driving licenses and vehicle registration are obviously essential. Expired documents are a no-no, so keep them updated. Think of it as keeping your house keys handy.
normalised: Driving licenses and vehicle registration are obviously essential. Expired documents are a no-no, so keep them updated. Think of it as keeping your house keys handy.

unnormalised: Finally, always be courteous. A little bit of patience and understanding goes a long way in making our roads safer and less stressful for everyone. Namaste!
